title: Community Fruit Tree Planting and Care Guide for Bare Root Trees

tasks.task: Digging a hole for planting a community fruit or nut tree.
subtasks: Using a digging fork or shovel to create a hole of appropriate depth and width.
Ensuring the hole is the correct size for the tree without compaction.
Positioning the tree roots downward to prevent rot and disease.
Soaking bare root trees in water for no more than six to eight hours prior to planting.
Breaking up native soil and returning it to the hole, adjusting for soil type (e.g., clay, sand).
Carefully backfilling the hole with native soil, avoiding air pockets through gentle tamping.
Ensuring the tree collar is level with ground surface to prevent drowning.
Clearing ground around the tree to reduce weed competition.
Laying down cardboard or similar mulch material against the tree trunk.
Applying compost and organic matter around the tree to improve fertility and retain moisture.
Adding mulch (e.g., leaves, wood chips) over the compost to suppress weeds and retain moisture.
Using hardware cloth or similar material to create a protective barrier around the trunk.
Securing the barrier with twist ties or fencing wire.
Staking the tree if necessary for support.
Initially watering twice a week, adjusting based on climate and weather.
Monitoring for signs of drought stress (e.g., wilting) and promptly addressing.
Maintaining the donut-shaped mulch ring to avoid burying the tree collar.
Applying additional compost and mulch annually, as needed.
Weeding around the tree base to prevent competition.
Digging a shallow hole or trench to bury the roots.
Packing the stored trees with soil and protecting from air and sunlight.
Covering with soil and tamping gently to secure.

tasks.task: Sharing knowledge and supporting community tree planting efforts.
subtasks: Promoting communityfruittrees.org for further information and support.
Encouraging tree owners to document their planting progress (photos, videos) for sharing.
